Key Arguments: Misinformation and disinformation have always existed and are part of human communication.
Individuals develop cognitive frameworks of trust to navigate misinformation, questioning the reliability and conflicts of interest of sources.
Historical examples show that authorities have often been wrong and resistant to new knowledge, such as in the cases of Galileo and Einstein.
Authorities are unreliable as arbiters of truth due to their inclination to preserve the status quo.
Open and robust public debate is the most effective way to resolve truth.
Notable Quotes: History has demonstrated that ‘authorities’ are wholly unreliable as arbiters of truth.
The only reliably effective methodology for resolving truth in any given field is open, robust debate in public forums.
Allowing any 'authority’, including one appointed by an elected government, to act as an arbiter of truth is fraught with danger of suboptimal outcomes.
